author: robocopsgonemad3303
content: I have a question I'm not quite sure how to google. How would i find a frequency distribution of contract calls? I've implemented a cache of contracts so we can avoid calculating JUMPDESTs redundantly, but I'm not sure how to sensibly set the size of the cache. Where could I answer "about how many different contracts are called every N hours?"

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Easiest is to modify your favourite client of choice to spit out the data you need and perform a full sync.
You might be able to query something like this over dune analytics (or other analytics sites) too

author: robocopsgonemad3303
content: perfect, I'll start with Dune, thx

author: gcolvin
content:
Once we have EOF, which deprecates dynamic uses of JUMP and JUMPI, I don't believe we need jumpdest tables at all.
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-3779-safe-control-flow-for-the-evm/6975
This EIP does not introduce any new opcodes, it just proposes a validation algorithm.

author: chfast
content: Is anyone running on Kovan here?

author: stakewars
content: Hey. Quick question; where can I check the amount of users still using pre 1.10.8 GETH vs 1.10.8?

author: timbeiko
content: Ethernodes will give you a rough proxy, <@!779882055910948895>: https://ethernodes.org/client/geth

author: timbeiko
content: it's not every user, and likely is biased towards more "consumer" nodes, but I assume the % are generally representative of discoverable nodes on the network

author: stakewars
content: Sounds good. Thank you!

author: stakewars
content: I see a bunch of 1.10.6 and 1.10.7

author: stakewars
content: I wish people would be a bit more attentive

author: stakewars
content: Question - why don’t GETH developers do something similar to the way Taproot was done on BTC? Wait until everyone updates, gain majority and then have it activate after 14 days or something like that in general…

author: stakewars
content: Instead of risk double spend

author: pipermerriam
content: The same thing would have happened under this mechanism if I have my facts correct.  A majority of the network was indeed upgraded, thus the correct fork "won" due to this majority

author: stakewars
content: So why do I keep hearing about “a double spend was possible” bc blah blah blah ETH bad ETH that lol. I’m sick of this lol

author: pipermerriam
content: I can only speculate... because the minority fork still held some non trivial percentage of the hash power and I believe the outdated nodes continued to build on that fork for some time.  A double spend would have been possible against anyone still anchoring to the wrong fork

author: stakewars
content: In the Taproot scenario isn’t it more like… miners upgrade to the new software BUT keep running per the old one, UNTIL new one is running on a majority of them thus SIGNALING that it can be turned on.

author: stakewars
content: This seems like we were hoping people would just update and that’s it. I really think this would have been a better approach. But again I’m not super techy so I’m not sure if what I’m saying is right

author: pipermerriam
content: And anyone still in the minority still lives on the wrong fork....  so we end up with the same situation...

author: pipermerriam
content: If you want to continue this discussion, feel free to ping me in <#595721451651465227> , keeping this channel free for other things

author: stakewars
content: Got it
